title: How to Make a Boxwood Wreath

steps.headline: Cut your boxwood into shorter pieces using pruning shears.
steps.description: You don't have to be very precise here, but aim to make the pieces between 8 and 10 inches (20.32 and 25.4 centimeters). It would be a good idea to have a few shorter ones and a few longer ones. For a 12-inch (30.48-centimeter) wreath, cut your boxwood into 4 to 6-inch (10.16 to 15.24-centimeter) sprigs. If the boxwood is dirty, rinse it with cool water first, then pat it dry with a paper towel.

steps.headline: Insert your first clipping your grapevine wreath.
steps.description: Choose a place on the outermost edge to start. Insert the end of the boxwood cutting 2 to 3 inches (5.08 to 7.62 centimeters) into the wreath. Angle the cutting so that it is flush against the wreath. Your grapevine wreath can be any side you want. The bigger it is, the more boxwood sprigs you will have to use. If your wreath is thin, make small bundles of 4 to 5 sprigs first. Tie the sprigs together with floral wire, then tie the bundles to the wreath with more floral wire.

steps.headline: Continue inserting the boxwood clippings until the wreath is full.
steps.description: Fill the outermost edge first, then start on the next row directly above it. Insert each clipping 2 to 3 inches (5.08 to 7.62 centimeters), and angle it so that it is resting against the wreath. Make sure that all of the clippings are pointed in the same direction. Do not cover the back of the wreath. Use the shorter clippings for the inside ring.

steps.headline: Fill in the gaps.
steps.description: Once you have completed your wreath, go back over it and look for any gaps. If you see any gaps, fill them in with shorter pieces of boxwood. Make sure that no grapevine (except for the back) is showing. If the sprigs won't stick, secure them with a drop of hot glue.

steps.headline: Neaten the wreath up.
steps.description: Go back over your wreath once again. Adjust the clippings so that they lay nicely. Trim away any that are unruly or that are sticking out too much.

steps.headline: Loop a thick ribbon around your wreath.
steps.description: Cut a long piece of wide ribbon and thread it through the center of your wreath. Tie the ends together into a tight knot to make a loop. For a nicer touch, consider tying the ends into a fancy bow instead. The hanging loop can be as long or as short as you want it to be.

steps.headline: Hang your wreath.
steps.description: Boxwood is pretty durable and it can last a long time. You can help it last even longer by squirting it with water a few times each week.

steps.headline: Get some faux boxwood greenery.
steps.description: You can find it in spray and garland form. How much you get will depend on the size of your grapevine wreath. Plan on using one garland or about four sprays of faux boxwood.

steps.headline: Pull the faux boxwood greenery apart.
steps.description: Simply pull the stems off of the garland or the spray. If you'd like, you can sort them by size.

steps.headline: Hot glue your first set of boxwood to the outermost edge of the grapevine wreath.
steps.description: Keep the sprig parallel to the wreath. Place a glob of glue just below the stem, and set the next sprig down. Keep doing this until the outermost edge is covered. Make sure that the sprigs are all pointing in the same direction and that they are overlapping. Your grapevine wreath can be any size. Keep in mind that the bigger the wreath, the more faux boxwood you'll need.

steps.headline: Continue hot gluing the sprigs until the entire wreath is covered.
steps.description: Make sure that they are all going in the same direction and that they are overlapping. You do not want the bare part of the sprigs to be visible. Save the smaller sprigs for the inner ring. You do not have to cover the back of the wreath.

steps.headline: Fill in any gaps.
steps.description: Go over your wreath carefully and note any gaps. If you see any, fill them in with extra sprigs of faux boxwood. Once again, you do not need to cover the back.

steps.headline: Neaten the wreath up.
steps.description: Go over your wreath, and pull off any strands left behind by the hot glue. This will give you a neater finish. Consider fluffing the boxwood out. This will give your wreath a fuller, more organic look.

steps.headline: Add a ribbon hanging loop.
steps.description: Cut a long piece of ribbon. Thread it through the center of your wreath. Tie both ends together into a knot or bow.

steps.headline: Hang your wreath.
steps.description: Faux boxwood can last a very long time, but it is still delicate. Keep the wreath away from rain. The rain won't hurt the glue or the boxwood, but it may cause the grapevine to rot.

text: Making a Real Boxwood Wreath Cut your boxwood into shorter pieces using pruning shears. You don't have to be very precise here, but aim to make the pieces between 8 and 10 inches (20.32 and 25.4 centimeters). It would be a good idea to have a few shorter ones and a few longer ones. For a 12-inch (30.48-centimeter) wreath, cut your boxwood into 4 to 6-inch (10.16 to 15.24-centimeter) sprigs. If the boxwood is dirty, rinse it with cool water first, then pat it dry with a paper towel. Insert your first clipping your grapevine wreath. Choose a place on the outermost edge to start. Insert the end of the boxwood cutting 2 to 3 inches (5.08 to 7.62 centimeters) into the wreath. Angle the cutting so that it is flush against the wreath. Your grapevine wreath can be any side you want. The bigger it is, the more boxwood sprigs you will have to use. If your wreath is thin, make small bundles of 4 to 5 sprigs first. Tie the sprigs together with floral wire, then tie the bundles to the wreath with more floral wire. Continue inserting the boxwood clippings until the wreath is full. Fill the outermost edge first, then start on the next row directly above it. Insert each clipping 2 to 3 inches (5.08 to 7.62 centimeters), and angle it so that it is resting against the wreath. Make sure that all of the clippings are pointed in the same direction. Do not cover the back of the wreath. Use the shorter clippings for the inside ring. Fill in the gaps. Once you have completed your wreath, go back over it and look for any gaps. If you see any gaps, fill them in with shorter pieces of boxwood. Make sure that no grapevine (except for the back) is showing. If the sprigs won't stick, secure them with a drop of hot glue. Neaten the wreath up. Go back over your wreath once again. Adjust the clippings so that they lay nicely. Trim away any that are unruly or that are sticking out too much. Loop a thick ribbon around your wreath. Cut a long piece of wide ribbon and thread it through the center of your wreath. Tie the ends together into a tight knot to make a loop. For a nicer touch, consider tying the ends into a fancy bow instead. The hanging loop can be as long or as short as you want it to be. Hang your wreath. Boxwood is pretty durable and it can last a long time. You can help it last even longer by squirting it with water a few times each week. Making a Faux Boxwood Wreath Get some faux boxwood greenery. You can find it in spray and garland form. How much you get will depend on the size of your grapevine wreath. Plan on using one garland or about four sprays of faux boxwood. Pull the faux boxwood greenery apart. Simply pull the stems off of the garland or the spray. If you'd like, you can sort them by size. Hot glue your first set of boxwood to the outermost edge of the grapevine wreath. Keep the sprig parallel to the wreath. Place a glob of glue just below the stem, and set the next sprig down. Keep doing this until the outermost edge is covered. Make sure that the sprigs are all pointing in the same direction and that they are overlapping. Your grapevine wreath can be any size. Keep in mind that the bigger the wreath, the more faux boxwood you'll need. Continue hot gluing the sprigs until the entire wreath is covered. Make sure that they are all going in the same direction and that they are overlapping. You do not want the bare part of the sprigs to be visible. Save the smaller sprigs for the inner ring. You do not have to cover the back of the wreath. Fill in any gaps. Go over your wreath carefully and note any gaps. If you see any, fill them in with extra sprigs of faux boxwood. Once again, you do not need to cover the back. Neaten the wreath up. Go over your wreath, and pull off any strands left behind by the hot glue. This will give you a neater finish. Consider fluffing the boxwood out. This will give your wreath a fuller, more organic look. Add a ribbon hanging loop. Cut a long piece of ribbon. Thread it through the center of your wreath. Tie both ends together into a knot or bow. Hang your wreath. Faux boxwood can last a very long time, but it is still delicate. Keep the wreath away from rain. The rain won't hurt the glue or the boxwood, but it may cause the grapevine to rot.

You don't have to be very precise here, but aim to make the pieces between 8 and 10 inches (20.32 and 25.4 centimeters).
It would be a good idea to have a few shorter ones and a few longer ones.
For a 12-inch (30.48-centimeter) wreath, cut your boxwood into 4 to 6-inch (10.16 to 15.24-centimeter) sprigs.
If the boxwood is dirty, rinse it with cool water first, then pat it dry with a paper towel.
Insert your first clipping your grapevine wreath.
Choose a place on the outermost edge to start.
Insert the end of the boxwood cutting 2 to 3 inches (5.08 to 7.62 centimeters) into the wreath.
Angle the cutting so that it is flush against the wreath.
Your grapevine wreath can be any side you want.
The bigger it is, the more boxwood sprigs you will have to use.
If your wreath is thin, make small bundles of 4 to 5 sprigs first.
Tie the sprigs together with floral wire, then tie the bundles to the wreath with more floral wire.
Continue inserting the boxwood clippings until the wreath is full.
Fill the outermost edge first, then start on the next row directly above it.
Insert each clipping 2 to 3 inches (5.08 to 7.62 centimeters), and angle it so that it is resting against the wreath.
Make sure that all of the clippings are pointed in the same direction.
Do not cover the back of the wreath.
Use the shorter clippings for the inside ring.
Fill in the gaps.
Once you have completed your wreath, go back over it and look for any gaps.
If you see any gaps, fill them in with shorter pieces of boxwood.
Make sure that no grapevine (except for the back) is showing.
If the sprigs won't stick, secure them with a drop of hot glue.
Neaten the wreath up.
Go back over your wreath once again.
Adjust the clippings so that they lay nicely.

Loop a thick ribbon around your wreath.
Cut a long piece of wide ribbon and thread it through the center of your wreath.
Tie the ends together into a tight knot to make a loop.
For a nicer touch, consider tying the ends into a fancy bow instead.
The hanging loop can be as long or as short as you want it to be.
Hang your wreath.
Boxwood is pretty durable and it can last a long time.
You can help it last even longer by squirting it with water a few times each week.
Making a Faux Boxwood Wreath Get some faux boxwood greenery.
You can find it in spray and garland form.
How much you get will depend on the size of your grapevine wreath.
Plan on using one garland or about four sprays of faux boxwood.
Pull the faux boxwood greenery apart.
Simply pull the stems off of the garland or the spray.
If you'd like, you can sort them by size.
Hot glue your first set of boxwood to the outermost edge of the grapevine wreath.
Keep the sprig parallel to the wreath.
Place a glob of glue just below the stem, and set the next sprig down.
Keep doing this until the outermost edge is covered.
Make sure that the sprigs are all pointing in the same direction and that they are overlapping.
Your grapevine wreath can be any size.
Keep in mind that the bigger the wreath, the more faux boxwood you'll need.
Continue hot gluing the sprigs until the entire wreath is covered.
Make sure that they are all going in the same direction and that they are overlapping.
You do not want the bare part of the sprigs to be visible.
Save the smaller sprigs for the inner ring.
You do not have to cover the back of the wreath.
Fill in any gaps.
Go over your wreath carefully and note any gaps.
If you see any, fill them in with extra sprigs of faux boxwood.
Once again, you do not need to cover the back.
Neaten the wreath up.
Go over your wreath, and pull off any strands left behind by the hot glue.
This will give you a neater finish.
Consider fluffing the boxwood out.
This will give your wreath a fuller, more organic look.
Add a ribbon hanging loop.
Cut a long piece of ribbon.
Thread it through the center of your wreath.
Tie both ends together into a knot or bow.
Hang your wreath.
Faux boxwood can last a very long time, but it is still delicate.
Keep the wreath away from rain.
The rain won't hurt the glue or the boxwood, but it may cause the grapevine to rot.
